pages.title: Syllabus
pages.body:
CS 540: Deep Learning Theory


Fall 2025










Course Description:
This course rigorously covers foundational concepts in learning theory, emphasizing theoretical analysis
  related to modern deep learning frameworks. Key topics include generalization analysis, VC-dimension,
  covering  numbers,  Rademacher  complexity,  stochastic  gradient  descent,  common  techniques  for  lower
  bound  analysis,  universal  approximation  results,  Neural  Tangent  Kernel  (NTK)  regime  optimization,
  benign overfitting, and mean-field analysis. Evaluation consists of four homework assignments, a take-home
  midterm exam, and a group final project. The course aims to equip students with the theoretical foundations
  necessary to engage with current research literature.
  




Prerequisites:
    




Advanced linear algebra
    




Probability and statistics
    




Machine learning at the level of CS446
    




Strong mathematical skills at the level of mathematical statistics and real analysis.






Class time: 
Mon, Wed, 11:00am–12:15pm, SC 0216. 
Lectures will be conducted in person and will not be recorded unless otherwise announced. 
Exceptions: the lectures on 
September 3 
and 
December 3 
will be held virtually via Zoom only.
  




Instructor: Prof. Tong Zhang (
tozhang@illinois.edu
)
                                                                                                  
                                                                                                  
    




Office: SC 2118

https://courses.grainger.illinois.edu/cs540/fa2025/

https://canvas.illinois.edu/courses/60407






Grading:

One group final project (15%), with 3–4 students per group
      




Read and understand a recent paper related to learning theory. Give a 20–25 minute presentation (5%)
      and write an approximately five-page report (10%).

pages.body:
CS 540 Final Project








   In the group final project, we target at 12 groups, with 3-4 students in each group, so that we
can go through 3 papers per class. Pick one of the papers listed below, or you may suggest your own
papers (but seek for approval). The listed papers cover recent research publications that use learning
theory to analyze neural networks (or related empirical findings). You should write a report and give a
presentation.
   
   
Presentation (5 Points)


25 minute, including QA, in-class project presentation (submit ppt prior to presentation). It should be structured as
follows.
  




Background of the research, prior works, and the problem this work tries to address, and why it is important
  (about 5-minutes)
  




Major proof ideas and technical innovations, and findings (about 10-15 minutes)
  




Conclusion, potential weakness of the work, follow-ups and extensions of the works if any (about 5 minutes)


Report (10 points)


You shall provide a summary of the paper in your report, showing understanding. You need to describe the
background, and problem studied, as well the high-level proof sketch. You shall also think about potential

pages.title: 4th Semester Option - Approval Required
pages.body:
The CS Graduate Academic Office is pleased to announce a revision to the “time to degree completion” policy that requires students in the Urbana MCS program to complete all degree requirements by the end of their third semester. This revision has been approved by the department with the goal of improving the student experience in your graduate program. Please carefully review
 
ALL
 the information.


Effective Fall 2023, newly admitted students to the Urbana MCS program will have the opportunity to fulfill all MCS degree requirements in four regular (Fall and Spring) semesters rather than three regular semesters under certain circumstances. Requests to complete the MCS requirements in four regular semesters must be pre-approved by the CS Graduate Advising Office.


All students who wish to enroll for a 4
th

Students who wish to complete the degree requirements in four semesters must have no more than 12 credit hours and no less than 3 credit hours remaining in their program requirements to complete in the fourth semester

th

pages.title: Give the Same Effort You Expect
pages.body:
We are here to help. However, a lot of important information about our degree program, internship policies, and other important things can be found with a simple search. We strongly urge our students to first make a reasonable effort to find information prior to reaching out to the academic advising office. This strategy helps you to find the answers to basic questions quickly and allows the academic advising staff to respond faster to the more complicated questions and administrative needs our students may have.


The same expectation of effort applies to how you write your emails. Take just a little extra time to ensure your message is clearly communicated to the recipient. Even if English isn't your first or best language, a quick spell check and rereading of the message before sending can do a lot to help the readability.


Unclear emails often result in a few extra emails back and forth just to get student and advisor on the same page. Here are some tips to make your emails as clear as possible so your advisor spends less time trying to decipher it and more time responding to it.




Always use your @illinois.edu email.
 In your initial message, give your name as it appears on your record and your UIN. This helps us find your record so we can address your specific issue. We will not respond to student questions sent from an external address.


A descriptive but brief subject line helps staff understand the context of your message, and also helps them find it easily later.



"Summer CPT Policy" is much better than "question".






Clearly state what you need, and ask (don't demand) for what help we can offer.



"I'm having trouble registering for CS 527. I get an error, 'Program Restriction'. Could you help me understand the issue?" is far better than the vague "I can't add a class. Help me add it."

pages.body:
Minimum Grades
: Any course taken for letter grade must have a grade of C or higher. Breadth courses must have a grade of B- or higher.
 
Some courses such as CS 491 and CS 591 are graded with S/U (satisfactory/unsatisfactory) grades rather than letter grades. An S is required to apply the credits towards the MCS degree. CS graduate students may not elect the credit/no-credit option for any coursework that can possibly be used toward the degree or that are needed to hold minimum registration.


Academic Standing
: A minimum 3.0 grade point average (GPA), corresponding to a grade of B, must be maintained to stay in all graduate programs and to graduate. This is often called being in Good Academic Standing. Students whose cumulative GPA falls below 3.0 or have earned below a 3.0 for a specific term may be placed on Academic Warning (formerly known as Academic Probation). The next page will go into more detail about the Warning and Drop statuses.


Evaluations
: During the second semester, MCS students are required to submit a self-evaluation and are also evaluated by the department. More information regarding the evaluation process is on the my.CS page in this orientation.

pages.title: Academic Warning and Drop Status
pages.body:
As mentioned in the last section, failure to maintain a 3.0 GPA (both term and cumulative) will result in the student not being in Good Academic Standing. The Graduate College calculates GPAs and standings after final grades are reported for the semester.
 


What is Academic Warning?


This is an academic status placed by the Graduate College when a student's cumulative and/or semester GPA has fallen below the minimum required (3.0). (Before Fall 2024 this status was called Academic Probation. Any references you see to Academic Probation are referring to what is now Academic Warning.)


What are the Consequences of Being on Warning status?


Students on Academic Warning are not eligible to hold an assistantship or fellowship unless they petition the Graduate College for an exception. Most importantly, the student has one semester while on Warning to improve their GPA above a 3.0. Failure to do so will result in the Graduate College placing the student on Drop status. All courses for future semesters will be dropped, and the student is dismissed from the Graduate College. For international students this can result in loss of visa status.


While Warning itself is not impossible to recover from, it is a serious situation to be avoided. MCS students on Warning will be contacted by the CS Graduate Advising Office to schedule a mandatory meeting with an Academic Advisor. This meeting will focus on making sure the student understands Academic Warning and the minimum GPA requirements, and also to form a plan to improve their academic performance going forward.


Students who are placed on "Drop" Status may appeal to be reinstated in the program. The CS Graduate Academic Advising Office will review appeals individually.

Registration Deadline

Failure to do so may result in late fees, loss of valid visa status for international students, loss of assistantship, and/or unapproved leave of absence. All CS students, except those on an approved leave of absence, must register for Fall and Spring term until they graduate. Students are not required to register for Summer term unless they are on CPT or on a fellowship.


Full-time Status
: All Professional MCS on-campus students are required to register for 12 graduate credit hours to maintain full-time status, unless a reduced course load is approved in their final semester. There are two exceptions to this:



Students that hold a 50% assistantship can be considered full-time with 9 credit hours.


Domestic students are permitted to register part-time (below 12 credits), though those with an assistantship are still required to hold at least 9 credits. Domestic students should discuss this with an advisor before proceeding with reduced registration.






Completion Timeline
: All degree requirements must be completed in 
three
 continuous semesters or less (counting only Fall and Spring terms). Domestic students enrolled part-time must complete all degree requirements within 5 years.




Students can take courses during Summer, but are not required to do so. Note that relatively few CS courses are offered in Summer.


Exceptions may be approved for students to request a 4th semester. These will be covered later in this course.


Students who complete all requirements prior to their third semester, such as in their second semester or during the Summer term, will be required to graduate at the end of that semester.

pages.title: Remember the Human
pages.body:
The anonymity that many social media sites offer can lead many people to think that the things they say online are not real or that they don't have real effects. It can be very easy typing on a keyboard in your home to forget that your words are being delivered to a person. While this is important to keep in mind for all online communication, they are especially so when interacting with student colleagues, supervisors, instructors, and advisors.


Be mindful of tone in your emails, as tone is difficult to communicate via text alone. Sarcasm, emojis, netspeak, and subtle humor can easily be misunderstood by the reader and result in miscommunication. Unless you already have an established rapport with the recipient, keep your emails plain, simple, and to the point.


Remember We Are Human


Emails to an individual advisor or to our office inbox are read by a real human being: a person with a job, responsibilities, stresses, and deadlines. We are here to help and support each of you. We expect all members of our community (including faculty, students, staff, alumni, and visitors) to uphold the highest standards of 
ethical, respectful, and collegial conduct
 and to be mindful of the impact of their actions on others. We do not tolerate discrimination, harassment, or abuse of power imbalances.


Be respectful and courteous in your language in your communications. Rude, offensive, or hateful language will not be tolerated. If you're angry or stressed, before sending the advisors a message ask yourself if you'd send the same message to your boss at a job? Would you say the same thing to someone in person? Hopefully the answer is that you'd be very careful about the words you'd choose, and the same applies to the CS graduate advising team.

pages.title: Respect the Academic Advisors' Time and Bandwidth
pages.body:
Since emails and texts are more or less instantaneous, people often expect the response to their questions and needs to be instant as well. You can't see the person on the other end, and you may not even know who they are, so it can be stressful to wait your turn when you aren't waiting in a physical line.


Just as the last page went over, remember that when you send an email, it goes to someone. That person may be busy with other emails, or they may need to consult a colleague or supervisor to get the right info to respond to you. In most professional settings, there are standards of reasonable timelines for responding to messages.


Respect Our Time and Bandwidth


Our office supports thousands of students. While your needs are important to us, please remember that our office is also assisting your peers with their needs at the same time. On top of this, many processes require input and approval from units outside of our control, such as the Graduate College, ISSS, and the Office of the Registrar, before the academic advisors can respond to your message(s).


Due to these factors, please allow up to 2-3 business days for us to respond to your emails or process your forms. Be mindful of working hours in your expectations. Emails sent in the evenings, over weekends, or on holidays will be addressed when we return to the office. We ask that you await our response over the expected wait time period. Here are some examples of not respecting the staff's time to respond to your inquiries in a timely manner:


    • Emailing a list of questions Tuesday morning and then sending an email Tuesday afternoon asking when we will respond.
    • Sending a form on Friday afternoon and entering the Advising Queue fist thing Monday morning asking why the form hasn't been processed.
    • Emailing one person and then sending the same request to more people thinking this will get you a quicker response.


We respond to all emails and requests in the order they were received, so please be patient. Sending the same request to multiple people only serves to confuse the process and duplicate effort. If you email someone, respect their time enough to wait for them to reply before seeking ways to force a faster response.


Be especially careful with the use of subject line modifiers such as "Urgent", "Time Sensitive", or all caps. We understand that important deadlines must be met. Trying to call extra attention to your message does not necessarily cause us to instantly skip to it. Remember, the academic office provides support to a very large number of students.

pages.title: Welcome to the Siebel School of Computing and Data Science at the University of Illinois
pages.body:
Effective July 1, 2024, the Department of Computer Science was elevated and transformed into the Siebel School of Computing and Data Science within The Grainger College of Engineering. Over the next few months, references to the department will be updated to refer to the school.


Welcome to the Fall 2024 Onboarding Course for the Master of Computer Science program! We are very excited that you have enrolled in the program and are about to start on this new venture.


The Onboarding Course is designed to get you started as an official student at the University of Illinois. It is completely self-paced, although we highly encourage you to finish it before the start of the semester (August 26
th
, 2024). This course must be completed by October 1
st
, 2024 at 4:00pm Central time with a score of 100% for each quiz. Registration for Spring 2025 is contingent upon completion of this course.


Please navigate to the Modules and start with Module 1. Please read each page, attempt the quiz and acknowledge completion of the onboarding. 


                                                                                         


Reminder:


It is important to note that there can be differences in requirements and policies depending on the term you first enter the Urbana MCS program. Keep this in mind as you interact with colleagues from other programs or cohorts. Know that we publish a new Onboarding for each cohort with information specifically relevant to them.


Learning Objectives:




Get to know the MCS degree program and academic progress requirements.


Plan your journey in the program by using the MCS Degree Planning Worksheet.


Review University and department policies on Academic Integrity.


Learn about departmental policies regarding internships.


Meet the CS Academic Office and learn how to access advising resources.


Learn about International Student Resources (optional module).


Learn ways to interact professionally with colleagues, faculty, and staff via email.


Register for courses and access the academic calendar. 


Become familiar with various academic resources at the University.




This course is composed of several topic modules. Each topic module covers important information that you need to know as a student of the University. Some modules include with mandatory quizzes, which are designed to ensure that you acquire the most important information from each module. The quizzes are not attached to academic credit hours. We highly encourage to your read information carefully in each module and complete the quizzes.

pages.title: Internships
pages.body:
The Computer Science Department generally supports students in their endeavor to pursue internships or other external work toward professional development in the CS field. Our expectation is that our graduate students are students first and foremost, so there are some limits on when a student may pursue an internship, especially if as a result they are seeking to reduce their course load or extend their expected time of study.


This module will cover some of the policies governing internships for Urbana-campus MCS students, for both domestic and international students.


Please note that the MCS program does not furnish students with these jobs (sometimes referred to as a co-op) or match them with prospective employers. Students seeking such career support should seek the 
University Career Center
 or 
Engineering Career Services
.

pages.title: Summer Internships
pages.body:
Summer is an optional term (unless it is the final term), so department policy allows part-time or full-time work. We do not restrict students from working over the summer while also taking summer courses, but we do caution students that summer coursework is often condensed into a relatively short term, and so time management is very key to success.


International students on an F-1 visa must obtain CPT work authorization to pursue a Summer internship in the U.S. during their studies. Please see Module 6 - International Student Resources for more information about this process.

pages.title: Fall/Spring Internships
pages.body:
The default expectation for Fall and Spring is that MCS students are making degree progress, thus internships during these semesters are more heavily restricted.




Part-time internships are typically allowed, with a full-time course load still required.


Full-time internships are only allowed during the 3rd semester, and require special approval from CS Graduate Advising.




International students on an F-1 visa must obtain CPT work authorization to pursue an internship in the U.S. Please see Module 6 - International Student Resources for more information about this process.

pages.title: 3rd Semester Full-time Internships
pages.body:
Beginning in Fall 2023, the CS Department’s policy was updated to allow Urbana MCS students the possibility of a full-time internship during the 3rd semester, with the goal of improving your experience during your graduate program.


An email is sent out to students during their 2nd semester with information about the approval process, including a link to a form. Below you can find general eligibility info.


Eligibility


All Urbana MCS students must meet the following criteria to be eligible to seek a third-term full-time internship. No exceptions will be made to these criteria.




Students must complete two 
consecutive
 regular Fall/Spring semesters as a full-time student. Those with any enrollment gap after the first term of enrollment are not eligible. For example, a student who started the MCS in Fall 2024 needs to be registered full-time for Fall 2024 and Spring 2025 to then be eligible for a full-time internship during Fall 2025.


Students must be in good academic standing at the time of the request being submitted. Students placed on Academic Warning (formerly known as Academic Probation) or Drop status by the Graduate College are not eligible.


Students must have no more than 12 credit hours of required coursework remaining to complete all MCS degree requirements in the final term after returning from the internship.


Students must have at least 3 credit hours of required coursework remaining to complete all MCS degree requirements in the final term after returning from the internship.




International students
: In addition to the above, international students are required to meet the following policies to be eligible and approved for full-time CPT during their 3rd regular semester.




International students will be required to register for 0 credits of ENG 510 during the internship semester, and are expected to adhere to all course guidelines and policies set by the Grainger College of Engineering to maintain their visa status.


Once approved as eligible, international students will need to submit a full-time CPT request, attaching ENG 510 approval and official job offer letter, by the deadline set by the Academic Advising Office.


International students are required to return as an in-person student to complete their final semester in the program to maintain their visa status. F-1 students may not complete the final semester remotely.




Other important notes
:




Students may 
not
 be enrolled in any classes during the internship semester, except for 0 credits of ENG 510 for international students on CPT. If you are registered for any other classes, we will ask you to drop them before we complete the approval process.



International students' F-1 status will be maintained by registration in ENG 510 for 0 credits.


Domestic students on full-time internship will be given instructions for requesting a Leave of Absence, and will not be registered at all during the internship semester.






Students may 
not
 hold any on-campus employment, such as a Teaching Assistantship, Research Assistantship, or hourly position.


Students registered for 0 credits may still have some tuition and/or fees assessed. For more information on rates, check with the 
Office of the Registrar
.


This opportunity is a privilege, not a guarantee. Not all students will be eligible based on the criteria set above. Not all students will find a job offer.


The CS Graduate Academic Office is not responsible for the timing of employers’ offers. Students are expected to work with prospective employers to get an offer that fits within valid dates, and to get the official job offer letter in a timely manner in order to progress the approval process.




The information included here is to give you an idea of the process in advance. We will send a formal announcement of the specific dates of the process for your cohort, typically during your 2nd semester. If there are any differences in the info presented here and in that email, please use the email info as the most accurate info.

pages.title: Priorities
pages.body:
We want to reiterate that while in the Urbana MCS program you are expected to prioritize academic progress over employment. 


Just because an internship is allowable doesn't always mean it is advisable. 
Students should use good judgement and time management to ensure they maintain healthy balance of work, study, and life. 


While internships are an important way to learn the real-world use of skills learned in the classroom, they are not strictly required to complete the MCS degree. It is not the department's responsibility to help students find internships, or to extend their studies if they face difficulty in a job search. Difficulty in a job search does not warrant program exceptions due to poor academic performance.

pages.title: CS 597 - Independent Study
pages.body:
CS 597 is an independent study course which allows for students to earn course credit for individual work with CS faculty (or officially affiliated faculty) who are approved to oversee graduate research. MCS students are eligible for this course, though it is much more prevalent for the research-based degrees (MS CS and PhD). MCS students can take this course under the following limits:




Can register for 2-4 credits in a semester. MCS students will not be approved for more than 4 credits of CS 597 in a single term.


A limit of 4 total credit hours of CS 597 can be used toward the MCS degree. Any excess credits after 4 will not be counted toward the MCS degree.


CS 597 can be counted as Advanced Coursework if taken as a single 4-credit registration.




Students cannot "combine" multiple instances of the course into Advanced Coursework.


Students cannot use both a CS 597 and a non-CS 5XX course as Advanced Coursework. One would be counted as Additional Coursework.








MCS students are discouraged from taking CS 597 multiple times, especially if there are other degree requirements remaining.


Registration in CS 597 requires approval from both the supervising faculty and the CS Department. 
Students interested in the course should first reach out directly to faculty to discuss their interest and come up with a 5-7 sentence project description. Next, the student should submit the project to the 
CS Independent Study portal
. The request is automatically routed to the faculty and to departmental staff for review. If approved at both levels, you will receive an email with instructions on how to add the course to your schedule.


Students are responsible for communicating with the instructor to agree upon timelines for progress, and students are responsible for completing the work by the end of the semester. CS Graduate Advising will not communicate with faculty on behalf of students.

pages.title: Transferring Previous Coursework
pages.body:
MCS students can possibly transfer previously completed coursework to be counted toward their MCS degree. There are 3 main types of credit transfers, but generally only one will apply to any given student and there is a total limit of 12 credits that may be transferred. Regardless of how many credits are transferred, remember that the MCS degree requires at least 24 credits be CS courses taken at UIUC. CS Dept policy requires students to complete at least one semester in our program before initiating such a request.


Coursework taken as an undergrad at UIUC


If you completed your bachelor’s degree at the University of Illinois Urbana Champaign and have completed at least one semester in our grad program, you my be able to submit a Change of Course Level (CCL) form to change certain courses from Undergraduate level to Graduate. Courses need to meet the following requirements:




Must be 4XX or 5XX level.


Courses can not have been used to meet 
any
 requirements for the bachelors degree.



This includes major requirements, credit hours, residency hours, GPA etc.






Course must have been taken for a credit amount that is valid for graduate students in the course.



Some courses (e.g., CS 415) do not offer 3 credits for grad students. So if it was taken for 3 as an undergrad, but grads can only earn 4, the course isn't eligible to move to a graduate degree.


See the Course Explorer listing to see how many credit hours a course offers. For example, 
CS 415
 says "3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours."






A letter grade of B or better if courses graded on standard letter grading, or Satisfactory if graded on S/U basis.



Courses elected for CR/NC grading are not eligible to be used toward a CS graduate degree.








Students seeking this type of transfer should first consult with an advisor for their undergraduate program or with their undergraduate college office to discuss which course(s) may be eligible to leave the BS degree. Afterward they can submit the 
CCL form
 to Joseph Zarnsy via email for review. The form must be approved by both the undergraduate college office as well as the Graduate College and ultimately the Office of the Registrar. Please allow several weeks for the entire process.


Coursework taken while in another UIUC department's graduate program


If you were previously in another graduate program at UIUC and completed courses that are valid for MCS degree progress, you may be able to petition the Graduate College to transfer them from the other program to CS. To be eligible to transfer:




Courses should be graduate-level 4XX or 5XX courses that are valid for MCS degree progress.


Courses can not have been used to meet 
any
 requirements for another degree.


A letter grade of B or better if courses graded on standard letter grading, or Satisfactory if graded on S/U basis.



Courses elected for CR/NC grading are not eligible to be used toward a CS graduate degree.








Students seeking this type of transfer should first consult with the other graduate program to determine if the course is eligible to be lost from that degree. Afterward they can submit a 
Graduate College petition
 to formally request the transfer. It is recommended you specifically list each course being requested along with the term completed. Once submitted, the request needs to be approved by both departments before being routed to the Graduate College for final approval and processing. Please allow several weeks for the entire process.


Coursework taken at another accredited university in the US


Graduate-level coursework completed at another university may be able to be transferred here to meet MCS requirements
.
 To be eligible to transfer:




Courses should be graduate-level courses related to Computer Science.


Courses can not have been used to meet 
any
 requirements for another degree or transcripted credential (minor, etc.).


A letter grade of B or better if courses graded on standard letter grading, or Satisfactory if graded on S/U basis.



Courses elected for CR/NC grading are not eligible to be used toward a CS graduate degree.








Students seeking this type of transfer should submit a 
Graduate College petition
 with the following documents attached.




Official transcript dated within 6 months of the date of submitting the petition.


Official letter from the Registrar, Academic Office, or other equivalent administrative body of that university stating that the courses in question were not used toward a degree or other transcripted credential.


A syllabus for each course.




Each course syllabus in question is reviewed by CS faculty, but ultimately the Graduate College has final say on whether or not the courses will be approved, and what they will count as if approved. This entire process can take up to 6 months.

pages.title: Academic Integrity and Honor Code
pages.body:
Policies and Definitions


The University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) Student Code provides comprehensive and authoritative guidelines related to academic integrity. To understand your rights and responsibilities as a graduate student at UIUC, please review 
Article 1, Part 4: Academic Integrity and Procedure 
of the Student Code at 
https://studentcode.illinois.edu/
.


The following constitute academic integrity infractions at UIUC: Cheating; Plagiarism; Fabrication; Facilitating Infractions of Academic Integrity; Bribes, Favors, and Threats; and Academic Interference.


The Honor Code of the Siebel School of Computing and Data Science is an additional required reading for this onboarding course.  Please review the Honor Code at 
https://siebelschool.illinois.edu/academics/honor-code
 for additional information about policies, procedures, and shared values in the community.


Each course offered at UIUC can have specific guidelines and expectations related to academic integrity, described in the course syllabus. Please carefully review each course syllabus so that you understand the expectations for each course. If you are unclear about course expectations, requirements, and other guidelines as they relate to academic integrity listed above, please do not hesitate to consult with your instructor or teaching assistants. Lack of knowledge is not an excuse for academic integrity violations.


Possible Sanctions


The following are recommended sanctions for cheating in a CS course (source: 
https://siebelschool.illinois.edu/academics/honor-code
)




First offense for cheating:




on an exam: zero on the exam


on a programming assignment, quiz, or written homework: zero on the assignment and final course grade is lowered by one whole letter grade.




Multiple instances of cheating of any kind: failure in the course.




It is your responsibility to be fully informed of the policies and practices above to help you maintain academic integrity as a graduate student at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.


Example


Here is an example scenario of cheating. Note that different courses may have completely different scenarios. One 500-level course required students to attend lectures and submit a report at the end of each lecture. Students could omit several reports without affecting their grade. However, several students submitted reports without attending the lecture. All these students were sanctioned with a reduced grade. Simply not submitting the reports would have likely had no negative effect on their grade.
